#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=CHAPTER XIV
#Text=Nana suddenly disappeared .
#Text=It was a fresh plunge , an escapade , a flight into barbarous regions .
#Text=Before her departure she had treated herself to a new sensation : she had held a sale and had made a clean sweep of everything -- house , furniture , jewelry , nay , even dresses and linen .
#Text=Prices were cited -- the five days ' sale produced more than six hundred thousand francs .
#Text=For the last time Paris had seen her in a fairy piece .
#Text=It was called Melusine , and it played at the Theatre de la Gaite , which the penniless Bordenave had taken out of sheer audacity .
#Text=Here she again found herself in company with Prulliere and Fontan .

#Text=Her part was simply spectacular , but it was the great attraction of the piece , consisting , as it did , of three POSES PLASTIQUES , each of which represented the same dumb and puissant fairy .

#Text=Then one fine morning amid his grand success , when Bordenave , who was mad after advertisement , kept firing the Parisian imagination with colossal posters , it became known that she must have started for Cairo the previous day .
#Text=She had simply had a few words with her manager .
#Text=Something had been said which did not please her ; the whole thing was the caprice of a woman who is too rich to let herself be annoyed .
#Text=Besides , she had indulged an old infatuation , for she had long meditated visiting the Turks .
#Text=Months passed --
#Text=she began to be forgotten .
#Text=When her name was mentioned among the ladies and gentlemen , the strangest stories were told , and everybody gave the most contradictory and at the same time prodigious information .
#Text=She had made a conquest of the viceroy ; she was reigning , in the recesses of a palace , over two hundred slaves whose heads she now and then cut off for the sake of a little amusement .
#Text=No , not at all !
#Text=She had ruined herself with a great big nigger !
#Text=A filthy passion this , which had left her wallowing without a chemise to her back in the crapulous debauchery of Cairo .
#Text=A fortnight later much astonishment was produced when someone swore to having met her in Russia .
#Text=A legend began to be formed : she was the mistress of a prince , and her diamonds were mentioned .
#Text=All the women were soon acquainted with them from the current descriptions , but nobody could cite the precise source of all this information .
#Text=There were finger rings , earrings , bracelets , a REVIERE of phenomenal width , a queenly diadem surmounted by a central brilliant the size of one 's thumb .
#Text=In the retirement of those faraway countries she began to gleam forth as mysteriously as a gem-laden idol .
#Text=People now mentioned her without laughing , for they were full of meditative respect for this fortune acquired among the barbarians .

#Text=One evening in July toward eight o'clock , Lucy , while getting out of her carriage in the Rue du Faubourg Saint-Honore , noticed Caroline Hequet , who had come out on foot to order something at a neighboring tradesman 's .
#Text=Lucy called her and at once burst out with :
#Text=“ Have you dined ?
#Text=Are you disengaged ?
#Text=Oh , then come with me , my dear .
#Text=Nana 's back . ”
#Text=The other got in at once , and Lucy continued :
#Text=“ And you know , my dear , she may be dead while we 're gossiping . ”
#Text=“ Dead !
#Text=What an idea ! ” cried Caroline in stupefaction .
#Text=“ And where is she ?
#Text=And what 's it of ? ”
#Text=“ At the Grand Hotel , of smallpox .
#Text=Oh , it 's a long story ! ”
#Text=Lucy had bidden her coachman drive fast , and while the horses trotted rapidly along the Rue Royale and the boulevards , she told what had happened to Nana in jerky , breathless sentences .
#Text=“ You ca n't imagine it .
#Text=Nana plumps down out of Russia .
#Text=I do n't know why -- some dispute with her prince .
#Text=She leaves her traps at the station ; she lands at her aunt's --
#Text=you remember the old thing .
#Text=Well , and then she finds her baby dying of smallpox .
#Text=The baby dies next day , and she has a row with the aunt about some money she ought to have sent , of which the other one has never seen a sou .
#Text=Seems the child died of that : in fact , it was neglected and badly cared for .
#Text=Very well ; Nana slopes , goes to a hotel , then meets Mignon just as she was thinking of her traps .
#Text=She has all sorts of queer feelings , shivers , wants to be sick , and Mignon takes her back to her place and promises to look after her affairs .
#Text=Is n't it odd , eh ?
#Text=Does n't it all happen pat ?
#Text=But this is the best part of the story : Rose finds out about Nana 's illness and gets indignant at the idea of her being alone in furnished apartments .
#Text=So she rushes off , crying , to look after her .
#Text=You remember how they used to detest one another -- like regular furies !

#Text=Well then , my dear , Rose has had Nana transported to the Grand Hotel , so that she should , at any rate , die in a smart place , and now she 's already passed three nights there and is free to die of it after .
#Text=It 's Labordette who told me all about it .
#Text=Accordingly I wanted to see for myself -- ”
#Text=“ Yes , yes , ” interrupted Caroline in great excitement
#Text=“ We 'll go up to her . ”
#Text=They had arrived at their destination .
#Text=On the boulevard the coachman had had to rein in his horses amid a block of carriages and people on foot .
#Text=During the day the Corps Legislatif had voted for war , and now a crowd was streaming down all the streets , flowing along all the pavements , invading the middle of the roadway .
#Text=Beyond the Madeleine the sun had set behind a blood-red cloud , which cast a reflection as of a great fire and set the lofty windows flaming .

#Text=Twilight was falling , and the hour was oppressively melancholy , for now the avenues were darkening away into the distance but were not as yet dotted over by the bright sparks of the gas lamps .
#Text=And among the marching crowds distant voices swelled and grew ever louder , and eyes gleamed from pale faces , while a great spreading wind of anguish and stupor set every head whirling .
